Lecture 26/27: Orbits

A regular polyhedra is a three dimensional solid where the faces are congruent regular polygons and such that the same number of faces meet at each vertex. There are exactly 5 regular polyhedra described below:

Homomorphism Theorem
Let \(G\) be a group and let \(N\) be a normal subgroup. Let \(\pi: G \rightarrow G/N\) be a homomorphism and let \(\phi : G \rightarrow H\) be a homomorphism.
Let \(K = ker(\phi)\) be a normal subgroup such that \(N \subseteq K\). Then
There exists a homomorphism \(\varphi': G/N \rightarrow H\) with formula $$ \begin{align*} \varphi'(aN) = \varphi(a) \end{align*} $$ and $$ \begin{align*} ker(\varphi') &= K/N = \{aN \ | aN \subseteq K\} \unlhd G/N \\ \phi'(G/N) &= \phi(G) \leq H \end{align*} $$
Axis (Dodecahedron) # of Axes Angle Order of \(g\) # of \(g\) Axis (Icosahedron) Cycle Type
Vertex/Vertex 10 \(\pm \frac{2\pi}{3}\) 3 20 3-cycle
Edge/Edge 15 \(\pm \frac{2\pi}{2}\) 2 15 2+2
Face/Face 6 \(\pm \frac{2\pi}{5}\) 5 12 5-cycle
Face/Face 6 \(\pm \frac{4\pi}{5}\) 5 12 5-cycle
Identity Rotation 1 1 e

So there are 60 total symmetries matching the rule (edges * 2). Note here that all the cycles are even cycles. In fact, \(G\) is isomorphic to \(A_5\).



References

  • Algebra: Abstract and Concrete by Frederick M. Goodman
